culturalObjects.name: Medieval King's Sword
culturalObjects.description: A medieval sword from a Kings collection. Solid gold handle engraved with a regal pattern. During the Middle Ages sword technology improved, and the sword became a very advanced weapon. The sword was often used as a symbol of the word of God. The names given to many swords in mythology, literature, and history reflected the high prestige of the weapon and the wealth of the owner.

culturalObjects.name: Medieval Barbute Helmet
culturalObjects.description: A visorless war helmet of 15th-century Italian design, often with distinctive Y shaped opening for the eyes and mouth. The name is first recorded in an inventory made for the Gonzaga family of Mantua in 1407. It can be considered as a specialised form of the sallet. The barbute resembles classical Greek helmets (most strikingly the Corinthian) and may have been influenced by a renewed interest in ancient artifacts which was common in this period.

culturalObjects.name: Medieval Battle Axe
culturalObjects.description: Battle axes were common in Europe in the Migration Period and the subsequent Viking Age, and continued to be employed throughout the rest of the Middle Ages; although they dipped in popularity during the 12th, 13th and 14th centuries, they did not disappear: King Robert I of Scotland used one to defeat Henry de Bohun in single combat at the start of the Battle of Bannockburn in 1314, and they enjoyed a sustained revival in use among heavily armored equestrian combatants in the 15th century.

culturalObjects.name: Knight's Shield
culturalObjects.description: A heavy metal shield used by the knights templar during the 11th century Crusades. The heater shield is a form of European medieval shield, developing from the early medieval kite shield in the late 12th century- as depicted in the great seal of Richard I and John.The term is a neologism, created by Victorian antiquarians due to the shape's resemblance to a clothes iron.
culturalObjects.associatedPeople: Saint Bernard of Clairvaux, Pope Innocent II
